body: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4bOCDP-rhuM - One talk I did on this for Subsurface 2023
Hey @glesperance, PyIceberg is actually at Pydantic v2 with PyIceberg 0.5.0, previous versions are at 1.10.x. This ticket is still open, but can be closed.
@ajantha-bhat @Fokko @rdblue @danielcweeks @amogh-jahagirdar @RussellSpitzer @flyrain
@ajantha-bhat, I've submitted a PR to quickly drop the table props to cut an RC asap. Could you look into other places that I missed?

@aokolnychyi can you run:

```sh
./gradlew revapiAcceptAllBreaks --justification "Spark 3.1 has been dropped"
```
I think it's a good idea to make sure we don't lower the advisory size if it is set in the Spark conf.
All api + core tests and checks passed, some engine CI jobs are still running but the table properties are not used there. I am going to merge this one to proceed with a release candidate.
Thanks, @Fokko @singhpk234!
+1 sounds like a good idea !
Thanks, @rdblue @singhpk234!
Maintainers: I've fixed the CI check in my first commit; please run the workflows again.
@Fokko @rdblue @danielcweeks @RussellSpitzer @flyrain @amogh-jahagirdar @nastra
Maybe we should update everything so that we have an "all" keyword that you can put in the version variables so that we don't need to update everywhere.

> Also, I'd like to find a way to add a mode that downloads files only on executors and not on the Spark driver.

One way I have seen folks hacking this around is via 
```
boolean onDriver = org.apache.spark.TaskContext.get() == null;
```

It would be interesting how we pass this info to the AsyncFileIO so that this mode can be set by a per engine based on the where it's accessing the AsyncFIleIO, probaly we can set this when we are broadcasting the table obj to the executors in spark ?

I was confused with where to start on GCP. I haven't dug too deep because I know there is no write support yet for pyiceberg (and I do not have Spark installed at all), but I did want to test a few things.

I know I need a catalog and it looks like the easiest one might be my PostgreSQL cloud SQL database:

```
catalog:
  default:
    type: sql
    uri: postgresql+psycopg2://username:password@localhost/mydatabase
    
 ```

But I did not see a description of how to create the actual table, if the database needs to be named specifically, what is the schema of the database table? Does it get created automatically if I just create a "iceberg" database with a iceberg user and password?

Since I am on GCP, I know of Dataproc as well and I have explored Dataplex before, but I am not sure if I can use that as a catalog for pyiceberg. If I can use this, I am not sure if there is a benefit compared to the PostgreSQL approach above either way.

I might be missing something - I am basing this information off of this documentation: https://py.iceberg.apache.org/configuration/

Let me check this one in a bit.

@aokolnychyi Thanks, I'm not 100% sure if it is a regression or intended. A test is failing that seems to make sense. I can take a look tomorrow with fresh eyes, but another set of eyes is very much welcome. Feel free to take over the PR.
cc @rdblue @amogh-jahagirdar

I don't think this change is correct. The logic should continue to be to clean up if strict cleanup is not enabled.

However, there is a behavior change here that is probably being hit by this test. We changed behavior and enabled strict cleanup for tables unless it is turned off by the catalog. This may leak files, but it is much safer and avoids table corruption on unknown exceptions.
Thanks, @nastra! Merged.

@advancedxy, thanks for your patience on this. I'm going to be looking at it more once the 1.4 release is out.

I have a couple of things that I'm thinking through on this:
* If we're updating the function, should we use a faster algorithm like XXH?
* Should we use a different approach to get to a bucket number rather than modulus?
* Should we make hash(str) and hash(int) the same to enable type promotion?

> @Kontinuation would you be interested in creating a PR?

Sure. I've submitted a pull request https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/8677

Hey @ajantha-bhat @Fokko, I've now updated the PR to remove the unecessary static files which took away more than half of the files so this should be much easier to look at.

For the rest of it, I explain the layout and rationale [a bit more in the README](https://github.com/bitsondatadev/iceberg/tree/new-docs/docs-new#build-process) now around the build process and what we are trying to achieve.

If you have any qeustions do let me know please! I think this is now in a state where I feel good sharing on the mailing list.

> I don't think this change is correct. The logic should continue to be to clean up if strict cleanup is not enabled.

I think it is a difference in understanding, if it is strict in cleaning up the files, I would expect it to clean it up. Anyway, good that we have the test and it is expected.

Positional deletes compaction is already handled 
https://iceberg.apache.org/docs/1.3.1/spark-procedures/#rewrite_position_delete_files

Do we need to keep this issue open for equality deletes or raise a separate issue?
Can compacting equality deletes also work? we may need some optimization to merge same filters with greater sequence number instead of reading each equality deletes and storing its content in a big file.
The `write.parquet.compression-codec` property is also set if the file-format is Avro
@nastra I'm having second thoughts for this one, shouldn't we make it required? https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/8600

Thanks for raising this Jan. I made a first attempt to fix this a while ago: https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/5338

For context, this has been changed with v2, because then there were both data and delete files. Since Iceberg does the lookup by field-id, this should not impose an issue, but it is good to get it fixed.
and how this file got corrupted, as we also face this issue alot?

> @bitsondatadev: Is it possible to split into two PRs?
> One is to move back the existing docs from iceberg-docs repo and another one is for refactoring?
> It may be easy to review the incremental change for the second PR.

I don't think this is a good idea. We don't want to add the iceberg-docs repo here, it's just unnecessary churn. I think the motivation is to be able to see what's changing, but that's fairly straightforward since this is not changing the content. Only the site structure and build are changing. The pages should say exactly the same thing.

RE: @RussellSpitzer cc: @ajantha-bhat 

> How should we be reviewing this? What is new, what is old? Is it just style and build?
 
All of this is a complete copy of the words (no content changed) of the existing site. So I would not focus on the words. There were quite a few broken links on the site that I decided to fix and had to in order to enable the interlinking between the static docs and the versioned docs.

So, I would not be reviewing the actual words, or we'll be fixing the entire grammar and misspellings that already exist in the docs today. That will have it's own PR after this.

The best way to test this is to understand [the proposed build process and how it works](https://github.com/bitsondatadev/iceberg/tree/new-docs/docs-new#build-process), and [install it locally](https://github.com/bitsondatadev/iceberg/tree/new-docs/docs-new#install) to get a grasp of the mechanics involved in the deployment and see if you agree with it or have any concerns. You should also poke around a bit to verify I didn't break many permalinks.

This will not be deployed once merged, just give us an initial base for the new docs to work from. Later I will start working on the grammar fixes and adding [Vale, a prose linter](https://vale.sh/) that can abide by various grammar and style standards that we'd like to enforce. 

Let me know if this makes sense.

I'm a little hesitant to make this change to the spec because I feel the spec is pretty clear.  Also, it almost reads like the spec is putting an ambiguous requirement ("reasonable attempt(s)") on engine implementors.

I can appreciate there's confusion around whether it's acceptable to assume that the field identifiers are unique, but currently the spec states that uniqueness is the intent, but not the guarantee.
I used a hadoop catalog for my testing. Worked fine! Thanks @RussellSpitzer .

I was finally able to resolve this issue with the in-memory catalog implementation.
Derby didn't work with iceberg so I thought of using the file system as the database based on the suggestion [here](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/7847). And to that, I had to use a Hadoop catalog(hadoop as the metastore) instead of derby.

And I also updated the test case to use HadoopCatalog instead of HiveCatalog to create tables which finally worked.

> @advancedxy, thanks for your patience on this. I'm going to be looking at it more once the 1.4 release is out.

That sounds reasonable and great to me.

> I have a couple of things that I'm thinking through on this:
> 
> * If we're updating the function, should we use a faster algorithm like XXH?

If we are going to add `bucketV2` as the new bucket function for both single-arg and multi-arg parameters. We can certainly use a faster/new hash algorithm. 

> * Should we make hash(str) and hash(int) the same to enable type promotion?

Currently, I don't think we can promote int to str due to the truncate/bucket(original) transform since we cannot produce same partition ing value. Unless we add more checks and restrictions about type promotion. 

I will also put more thinkings in this, and let's discuss after 1.4 is released .
Would like to see some more discussion around this. And would like to work on this too.
The multi-arg transform spec is up for review now @rakesh-das08 , please check that out. It's the first step

Good point about the truncate transform not matching. We'll have to check when promoting types that there aren't incompatible transforms either way so we shouldn't over-complicate the bucket function to accomplish this.

I'm closing this one since we're migrating to the iceberg-python repository. I see some great discussion here. We're already moving stuff to C++, and Arrow is currently still an optional dependency, so I think we made the right decision to implement the types ourselves. Also, the types in Python are just a tiny wrapper around the C++ object and a lot of stuff is not available in the Python API.
